reviewText: I love the Chevy Chase Vacation movies...which makes it hard when he speaks publicly about his political views. Great movies, funny, funny, funny...and then he comes off as a liberal robot without a clue. If these movies weren't so dear to me as a reminder of my youth I would NOT watch them. It's one of those situations where you have to close your eyes to his political views and just enjoy the movie...which is becoming increasingly necessary with Hollywood these days. Some movies/celebrities deserve to be boycotted, though, when they cross the line. Chevy Chase has kept his political mouth shut lately so I applaud him for that and will watch his movies and laugh.
summary: Love His Movies...Even if He is Weird

reviewText: IMPORTANT NOTE: The "child's review" above was written by me, but I accidentally chose the wrong attributes when I submitted it and Amazon tells me they cannot delete it. I reposted it under my own name almost immediately after submitting it, which is why this review is so similar.Warner Brothers (or possibly this site) appears to be gouging people with their pricing on this entry in their budget-priced line of repackagings called the 4 Film Favourites collection. Most of these retail for about ten to fifteen dollars. All contain two discs, two movies per disc, one movie per side. Nearly all of them port over any extras available on the previous editions.In this case, you get the special edition versions of the first three Vacation movies (commentaries, bonus features, etc.), and the regular version of Vegas Vacation. HOWEVER, content-wise, this "Ultimate Vacation" edition is actually a Four Film Favourites edition, only you'd never know it because Warner has squeezed the amaray into a deceptive cardboard slip sleeve that obscures both the actual sleeve art underneath as well as the bonus features and criteria for each film available in the set.Thus, holding this set in your hands in a store, for example, you wouldn't be able to tell if the films within are widescreen, which they are. And the only way to know that is to buy find the set WITHOUT the sleeve, which seems impossible in the U.S. at the time of writing. You'll know the cheaper collection if you do see it because the artwork looks just like the other sets in the series (Ocean's Collection, Nightmare on Elm Street Collections, Matrix Collection, Stallone Collection etc.), only with blue borders as opposed to the standard black (or pink for the romance 4-film sets). One saving grace of the listing for this set here at Amazon: the product images contain a shot of the back of the amaray case insert sleeve (which you can't see if you hold the actual set in your hands), which reveals that it's patterned after the 4 Film Favourites releases.Again, I warn you: if you buy this "Ultimate Vacation" collection at $36, you are not getting a fair price. I purchased this off the shelf at a Canadian record store for about thirteen dollars, and have since seen it in Wal-marts up here for $9.83 alongside others in the 4 Film Favorites line. Not sure why this set is taking so long to price-drop in the U.S.By the way, the set itself is fantastic. Four films that take up the space of one, and all but one porting over the extant special editions. Highly recommended, provided you can find it considerably cheaper than the average going rate here and elsewhere. My three-star rating is largely in response to the pricing discrepancies being used, presumably by Warner, to gouge customers for something that is part of a much larger, and much cheaper, series of four-film DVD sets. Otherwise, this set would rate at least 4 stars, possibly 5.
summary: Overpriced compared to ALL other 4 Film Favorites collections!!

reviewText: This is one of the funniest comedy series ever to be made.  Chevy Chase is really on top of his game in these films.  You can probably enjoy most of these films with your family, but number 2 has quite alot of nudity, and number 1 has some swears but i'm sure your kids will be able to watch them with you.  In every film, they change the kids to make them stay around the same age, that's what chevy chase said in the commetary in the second one.Vacation- very funny with great plot and actors.  This by far would have to be the funniest of the whole series.  Since this is a special edition, they put in alot of features which was great because the non special edition version of this dvd had barely any features.  The commentary in this is nice.  The whole family does the commentary.European Vacation- this is a hilarious sequel to the classic comedy.  It's not as good as Christmas Vacation or the original Vacation but don't let that fool you, it's still a movie that will make you laugh all the way through it.  The special features do lack on this disk for all we get is a trailer and a commentary by Chevy Chase (which sucked, i'm not kidding).  Anyway, this is still a hilarious film.Christmas Vacation- this is just as good as the first one.  It will make you howl with laughter.  This is the perfect Christmas comedy and the family could watch it.  Now, warner bros box sets usually make the first one a special editon, but it this box set, the first and this one get the special edition treatment.  This has the most features out of all the disksVegas Vaction- what can i say, this was a funny movie, but wasn't that strong. mostly because national lampoons didn't make it.  But it's still a funny movie and is really a family movie.  This is an ok disk when it comes to features, but what can you do.So, buckle up and get ready to ride with the Griswalds in a non-stop pack of laughter.

reviewText: If you love the National Lampoon Vacation movies, this is the right set for you. They come with new special features, behind the scenes featurettes, commentaries and more. The only weak link in the series is perhaps European Vacation, but apart from that all the movies are hilarious and well worth owning as a complete set. They also leave out the dreaded movie starring cousin Eddie as the main character, so you don't have to worry about paying any money for that dud.
summary: Best of Chevy Chase and National Lampoon

reviewText: There are 4 films in this imported Irish collection: National Lampoon's Vacation, European Vacation, Christmas Vacation and Vegas Vacation. You get the unrated versions of the movies. While I admit that I love all 4 films I must say this set is somewhat disappointing in terms of quality and extras (although it is a step up from the DVDs). None of the legendary deleted scenes (as mentioned in the interesting documentary) are included and both the audio commentaries are fairly bland. Overall, the picture and audio quality are average and in need of a good remastering. These are 4 star films in a 2 star package. The price is right so it could work as a value pack but I wish this was a deluxe collection. Region 2/B digital copy codes do not work in the US.Video Resolution: 1080p | Aspect Ratio: 1.78:1Language: English DTS-HD Master AudioSubtitles: English, French, SpanishBonus Content:Vacation: Trailer, Introduction (1 min.), Documentary (85 min.)European Vacation: Audio CommentaryChristmas Vacation: Audio Commentary, TrailerVegas Vacation: Trailer
summary: National Lampoon's Vacation Films on 4-Disc Imported Irish Blu-ray Boxset

reviewText: I'm glad Warner Bros. finally got the good idea to combine the four "Vacation" movies in one DVD package. Chevy Chase--and most certainly, Beverly D'Angelo--did some of their best work here, even if the road has bumps along the way. Let's go through the lineup..."Vacation" (1983) still stands as the first & best of the bunch, back when the premise was fresh, the satire had plenty of bite, and the laughs were frequent (and unforgivingly crude). Chase plays Clark Griswold, the ultimate boob of a father who takes his (reluctant) family cross country from Chicago to California to Wally World, a beloved Disney-esque theme park. The running joke of the series is that Clark watches his carefully made plans of a "perfect vacation" go down the tubes as he ultimately goes off the deep end and sucks his family into "the tenth level of hell". Ugly car rentals, asking for directions in a bad part of town, falling asleep at the wheel, unwanted relatives (courtesy of the great Imogene Coca and Randy Quaid as hick Cousin Eddie), on-the-road flirtations (a fetching Christie Brinkley), and kids getting corrupted are all ripe for parody. You'll see lots of familiar faces along the way: Eugene Levy, Brian Doyle Murray, James Keach, and John Candy, to name a few. John Hughes kicked off his prolific 80's career writing this comedy, with Harold "Caddyshack" Ramis directing."European Vacation" (1985) is a notch or two below the original. Not a bad sequel; just uneven. It starts off well with a goofy parody of game shows (John Astin hosts with oily lecherous glee) as the Griswolds win (just barely) a trip to you-know-where. There's an amusing montage of dream sequences on the way. Once there, the Griswolds do their best to destroy such tourist attractions as Stonehenge and Oktoberfest, and deal with overly polite Britishers (Eric Idle nearly steals the show as a masochistic bicyclist), not-so-nice French people, and target all the European culture. The ever-reliable D'Angelo provides some of the best laughs, but it's not quite enough to salvage the movie. By the time it reaches the climactic kidnapping/chase scene, it gradually runs out of steam."Christmas Vacation" (1989) is arguably the best sequel to the original. Again, Hughes pens a script that effectively deflates with mean-spirited glee what has to be the most bloated & over-commercialized holiday of the year. How many Americans have foolishly risked their necks to put a thousand lights on their roof? Chase excels, unsurprisingly, at physical comedy, and he's hilarious. The crazy quest to find the perfect tree, a house overrun by relatives (including the welcome return of Randy "Cousin Eddie" Quaid & Miriam "Cathy" Flynn, sorely absent from the last "Vacation"), snobby Yuppie neighbors (look for a pre-"Seinfeld" Julia Louise Dreyfuss), callous bosses (Brian Doyle Murray), lack of holiday funds...the list goes on. Chase's subsequent meltdown is priceless. And Quaid as Eddie steals nearly every scene he's in with his mischievous grin & mooching ways. Note that the Griswold kids this time are played by future stars Juliette Lewis (Audrey) & Johnny "The Big Bang Theory" Galecki (Rusty). For all the sappy holiday fare offered, this is the perfect antidote as a comedy that quickly becomes a tasteless train wreck (though electrocuting a cat is a bit harsh)."Vegas Vacation" (1997) is a comedy that came down the pike a bit too late. While it has its moments (the Hoover dam sequence and D'Angelo's hilarious duet with Wayne Newton) and is probably funnier than most comedies of the time, it just seems that much of the fun & pointed satire of the franchise has evaporated. The title explains it all, once again, as Clark takes the family to the "holy land" where the kids get into all kinds of mischief, Clark loses his shirt, and Ellen is wooed by Newton (!!). Even Christie Brinkley returns in an in-joke cameo that reminds us of "Vacations" past. Thankfully, Quaid & Flynn return in their roles to brighten things up. But Chase's usual egocentric humor & smirk seem half-hearted, although D'Angelo, as usual, gives it her best shot. The movie sort of wobbles to a limp unfunny finish.So here's the whole franchise with its highs & lows. Good entertainment at a good value!
summary: Finally, you can take all the "Vacations" in one package

reviewText: The original vacation is a classic! Wollyworld and the road trip through the desert are great!European vacation is probably the least known/popular entry in the series and for good reason, it's probably the least funny but not completely awful. Christmas Vacation is my favorite! An aboslute classis in every way. Cousin Eddie and the grumpy neighbors highlight what is a quintessential Christmas classic. Vegas Vacation is probably my second favorite. You see the return of Cousin Eddie yet again and you have the whiney voiced blackjack dealer from Princess Bride that is totally hilarious. I really don't see Chevy Chase making anymore of these so it is (for the time being) the definitive collection of the National Lampoon Vacation movies (there are some spinoffs but these are the original 4).
Title: N/A
